fields.description:
This can occur when using incremental synchronization, on an LDAP directory that has users with repeated (or differing by case only) username attributes.

HTR:
 * configure an ldap directory (tested with AD2012), use 'mail' as the username attribute
 * add a user with mail 'user1@user1'
 * run a full sync
 * add a second user with the same mail, but different user details
 * run an incremental sync

Actual results:
* each incremental sync swaps the user that is visible in Crowd

Expected results:
* users visible in Crowd remain stable
fields.summary: If two ldap users have the same  username attribute, incremental sync might cyclically rewrite them each sync

fields.description:
This can occur when a configuration of an existing directory is changed, so that the usernames of the users in the directory are no longer unique.

HTR:
* configure an ldap directory (tested with AD2012)
* add two users with different samAccountName ('user1', 'user2'), same mails ('mail')
* set Crowd to us samAccountName as the username attribute, do a full sync
* set Crowd to use mail as the username attribute, do a full sync

Actual results:
* during first sync both users get selected for update (getUsersToAddAndUpdate)
* during first sync 'user1' gets renamed to 'mail' (which is okay), then 'user2' tries to use 'mail' as the username, that one is busy, so it renames 'user1' to 'mail #1' ('forceRenameUser'), and names 'user2' mail
* during next sync the user who's now named 'mail #1' get selected for update (getUsersToAddAndUpdate)
* the user gets renamed to 'mail', but before that the previous user gets renamed to 'mail #2'
* the users get renamed over and over again during subsequent syncs 

Expected:
* the directory ends up in a stable state after synchronization
fields.summary: Previously synchronised users that now have the same username LDAP attribute get cyclically renamed each sync

However I'm getting these errors now:
{{2016-11-24 13:51:34,576 http-bio-8095-exec-20 INFO [directory.ldap.util.DirectoryAttributeRetriever] Skipping attribute objectGUID because its value <7\uFFFD\u039F\uFFFD\uFFFDbK\uFFFD\uFFFD<\uFFFDkC\uFFFD\b> is not XML safe}}

KB article tells to use Microsoft AD type instead: https://confluence.atlassian.com/jirakb/skipping-attribute-objectguid-because-its-value-xxx-is-not-xml-safe-744326956.html
Which brings us back to problem n°1: no empty base DN's

fields.description:
Freemarker templates in my own plugin (https://marketplace.atlassian.com/plugins/com.zenofx.crowd.upm/server/overview) cause the following exception:
{code:java}java.lang.NoSuchMethodError: freemarker.ext.jsp.TaglibFactory.setObjectWrapper(Lfreemarker/template/ObjectWrapper;)V
org.apache.struts2.views.freemarker.FreemarkerManager.buildScopesHashModel(FreemarkerManager.java:368)
org.apache.struts2.views.freemarker.FreemarkerManager.buildTemplateModel(FreemarkerManager.java:539)
org.apache.struts2.views.freemarker.FreemarkerResult.createModel(FreemarkerResult.java:301)
org.apache.struts2.views.freemarker.FreemarkerResult.doExecute(FreemarkerResult.java:182)
...
{code}
Probably a version mismatch between freemarker (2.3.21) and Struts2 (2.3.29) in the Crowd installation - IMHO freemarker is too old. The default object wrapper changed in freemarker 2.3.22. When updating freemarker to 2.3.24-atlassian-2 in WEB-INF/lib of the Crowd installation, everything works as expected.

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
Currently, CROWD in a case of any error in the login process returns an error "Can not connect to... check login and password". Most of the time such error message can be confusing because it's shown even when everything is fine with login and password but the problem with connection.
h3. Suggested Solution
Implement the recognition of the following issues during the login:
* Connection timeout
* User credentials issue
* SSL handshake fail
* Other SSL issues
* it would be brilliant if application will be able to warn user that SSL chain loaded is self-signed or if it contains no intermediate / root certificate
fields.summary: Improve handlers for the connection issues during the login

fields.description:
Fine, there are dozens of settings files, among them are application components settings
 * crowd.properties for crowd service
 * crowd.properties for crowd client
 * build.properties for application itself
 * server.xml - for Tomcat
 * ... and so on

Can all this be concentrated just in one file having self-explanatory sections?

Or, at least, at one folder, having files with self-explanatory names?

What about config includes support?

Wouldn't it be better if all configs retain one format (fine then, let it be XML, not JSON or INI)?

Why should I store domain and port settings for service at crowd.properties instead of Tomcat server.xml (what seems to me slightly more convenient)?

I think, configuration process will be much more easier after these optimizations, however, maybe, I'm wrong, and there is reason to have several configs with same logics and same names in several dirs

Maybe, the best way to implement is to concentrate as much configuration as possible at web-interface?
fields.summary: config standards

fields.description:
h5.Environment
# Microsoft Active Directory
# Two or more directories defined in Crowd, each with Incremental Sync enabled
# Each directory has a Base DN of {{OU=Users,DC=example,DC=com}}
# Each directory has an empty Group DN (i.e, groups can come from anywhere below the base DN, and are available to both directories)
# The first directory has a UserDN set to {{OU=Finance}}
# The second directory has a UserDN set to {{OU=Marketing}}
# A user, {{test}} exists in {{Finance}}
# A group, {{SomeGroup}} exists in the Base DN, and is available to both directories
# The {{test}} user is a member of this group

h5.Steps to reproduce
# Sync the directories - the {{test}} user will appear in the directory pointing to {{Finance}}
# Move the {{test}} user to the {{Marketing}} OU
# Sync the directories again

h5.Expected Results
# The membership for {{SomeGroup}} should be present in the second directory (that points to {{Marketing}})

h5.Actual Results
# The membership for {{SomeGroup}} is not present in either directory

h5.Investigation
An incremental sync against Active Directory checks the {{uSNChanged}} attribute of each object. If the object has not changed, it is not updated in an AD Sync. When a user is moved, there isn't an update to the group directly to point to that user's new location. AD is doing under-the-hood changes to that groups' membership that does not trigger an update to {{uSNChanged}}.

h5.Impact
The loss of memberships can be painful to diagnose and is unexpected in this configuration.

h5.Is this a bug? / Workarounds
No, because Crowd is working from what AD provides. Performing a full synchronisation, or updating the group (then performing an incremental sync) will produce the required results. This only needs to be done once after the move, subsequent incremental syncs will function correctly.

h5.What is the suggested enhancement?
Provide an option in Crowd for it to always re-evaluate group memberships during an incremental sync. While this may be a performance hit (and it should be labelled as such) we should provide the option to ensure memberships are consistent and correct after users are moved in the directory.
fields.summary: Provide a feature for Crowd to always re-evaluate group memberships in Active Directory with Incremental Sync

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
CROWD showing error messages for end users in raw format received directly from LDAP directory even though the common error code is in the message. Seeing the error message is good for the administrator, but for end users, it can be confusing in some cases.
h5. Business case
If the user entered the password which doesn't satisfy the LDAP complexity rules he/she will receive LDAP error 53 with part of stack trace:
 !Bildschirmfoto 2016-09-15 um 17.01.33.jpg|thumbnail! 
As a result, the end user confused about the real root cause and create a support request for every occurrence. So it put additional load both on internal help desk as well as on Atlassian Support.

h3. Suggested Solution
Add human readable messages for [Common User Management Errors|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/KB/Common+User+Management+Errors] together with a short link to the documentation (to simplify troubleshooting).
 
 
h3. Workaround 
Direct the internal helpdesk to Atlassian KB: [Common User Management Errors|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/KB/Common+User+Management+Errors]
fields.summary: Do not show ldap errors for non admin operations

fields.description:
h3. Summary

When Crowd is configured to use two-way SSL by setting {{clientAuth="true"}} in server.xml, Embedded Crowd clients fail to connect to it with a {{bad_certificate}} error.

h3. Environment
* Crowd 2.8.3 with {{clientAuth="true"}} in server.
* FishEye 4.2.0
* JIRA 6.4.3

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Generate a self-signed certificate for Crowd
# Configure Crowd for SSL and set {{clientAuth}} to true
{code}<Connector port="8443" protocol="org.apache.coyote.http11.Http11Protocol"
           maxThreads="150" SSLEnabled="true" scheme="https" secure="true"
           clientAuth="true" sslProtocol="TLS" truststoreFile="/usr/lib/jvm/java-8-oracle/jre/lib/security/cacerts" />{code}
# Generate a self-signed certificate for FishEye/Crucible
# Configure FishEye for SSL
{code}<web-server context="/fecru" site-url="https://jeffjeff.office.atlassian.com/fecru">
<http bind=":8060" /><ssl keystore="/var/atlassian/application-data/fecru/ssl/keystore.kst" bind=":8061" keystore-password="changeit" truststore-password="changeit" truststore="/usr/lib/jvm/java-8-oracle/jre/lib/security/cacerts"><proxy-info/><excludeProtocols><protocol>SSLv3</protocol></excludeProtocols></ssl></web-server>{code}
# Set {{FISHEYE_OPTS}} to specify the keystore
{code}FISHEYE_OPTS="-Djavax.net.ssl.keyStore=/var/atlassian/application-data/fecru/ssl/keystore.kst -Djavax.net.ssl.keyStorePassword=changeit"{code}
# Import the FishEye certificate into the truststore of the JVM for Crowd
# Import the Crowd certificate into the truststore of the JVM for FishEye
# Restart both Crowd and FishEye
# Create a User Directory in FishEye pointed to the secure URL for crowd and click Test

h3. Expected Results

The test connection is successful

h3. Actual Results

The UI displays the following message:

{code}Connection test failed. Response from the server:
javax.net.ssl.SSLHandshakeException: Received fatal alert: bad_certificate{code}

The below exception is thrown in the {{atlassian-fisheye-YYYY-MM-DD.log}} file:
{noformat}
2016-10-07 13:55:57,100 ERROR [qtp106999035-231 ] com.atlassian.crowd.embedded.admin.ConfigurationController ConfigurationController-handleSubmit - Configuration test failed for user directory: [ Crowd Server], type: [ CROWD ]
com.atlassian.crowd.exception.runtime.OperationFailedException: javax.net.ssl.SSLHandshakeException: Received fatal alert: bad_certificate
        at com.atlassian.crowd.embedded.core.CrowdDirectoryServiceImpl.testConnection(CrowdDirectoryServiceImpl.java:78) [embedded-crowd-core-2.8.8.jar:?]
        at com.atlassian.fecru.user.crowd.DelegatingCrowdDirectoryService.testConnection(DelegatingCrowdDirectoryService.java:29) [fisheye.jar:?]
        at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke0(Native Method) [?:1.8.0_101]
...
Caused by: com.atlassian.crowd.exception.OperationFailedException: javax.net.ssl.SSLHandshakeException: Received fatal alert: bad_certificate
        at com.atlassian.crowd.integration.rest.service.RestExecutor$MethodExecutor.andReceive(RestExecutor.java:493) [crowd-integration-client-rest-2.8.8.jar:?
]
        at com.atlassian.crowd.integration.rest.service.RestCrowdClient.searchUs
ers(RestCrowdClient.java:586) [crowd-integration-client-rest-2.8.8.jar:?]
        at com.atlassian.crowd.integration.rest.service.RestCrowdClient.testConnection(RestCrowdClient.java:574) [crowd-integration-client-rest-2.8.8.jar:?]
        at com.atlassian.crowd.directory.RemoteCrowdDirectory.testConnection(RemoteCrowdDirectory.java:839) [crowd-remote-2.8.8.jar:?]
        at com.atlassian.crowd.embedded.core.CrowdDirectoryServiceImpl.testConnection(CrowdDirectoryServiceImpl.java:69) [embedded-crowd-core-2.8.8.jar:?]
        ... 182 more
...
Caused by: javax.net.ssl.SSLHandshakeException: Received fatal alert: bad_certificate
        at sun.security.ssl.Alerts.getSSLException(Alerts.java:192) [?:1.8.0_101]
        at sun.security.ssl.Alerts.getSSLException(Alerts.java:154) [?:1.8.0_101]
        at sun.security.ssl.SSLSocketImpl.recvAlert(SSLSocketImpl.java:2023) [?:1.8.0_101]
        at sun.security.ssl.SSLSocketImpl.readRecord(SSLSocketImpl.java:1125) [?:1.8.0_101]
        at sun.security.ssl.SSLSocketImpl.waitForClose(SSLSocketImpl.java:1769) [?:1.8.0_101]
        at sun.security.ssl.HandshakeOutStream.flush(HandshakeOutStream.java:124) [?:1.8.0_101]
        at sun.security.ssl.Handshaker.sendChangeCipherSpec(Handshaker.java:1083) [?:1.8.0_101]
        at sun.security.ssl.ClientHandshaker.sendChangeCipherAndFinish(ClientHandshaker.java:1222) [?:1.8.0_101]{noformat}
 
h3. Notes

* The JVM is able to communicate successfully between the Crowd and FishEye server.
** Crowd to FishEye
{code}$ java SSLPoke fecru.internal.jeffjeff.local 8061
 
Successfully connected{code}
** FishEye to Crowd
{code}$ java -Djavax.net.ssl.keyStore=/var/atlassian/application-data/fecru/ssl/keystore.kst -Djavax.net.ssl.keyStorePassword=changeit SSLPoke crowd.internal.jeffjeff.local 8443
 
Successfully connected{code}
* An Application Link can successfully be establish between FishEye and Crowd, suggesting that this bug lies in the REST Client of Embedded Crowd
* FishEye can be replaced with JIRA, Confluence, or Bitbucket Server and the results would be the same
* With JVM SSL debugging turned on, the failure is caused when the client certificate is not found
{code}*** ServerHelloDone
Warning: no suitable certificate found - continuing without client authentication
*** Certificate chain
<Empty>{code}
* On a successful connection (SSLPoke or AppLink), the client certificate is found
{code}*** Finished
verify_data:  { 29, 223, 122, 244, 160, 159, 178, 222, 47, 13, 84, 173 }
***
qtp106999035-239, WRITE: TLSv1.2 Change Cipher Spec, length = 1
matching alias: fisheye
*** Certificate chain
chain [0] = [
[
  Version: V3
  Subject: CN=fecru.internal.jeffjeff.local, OU=Unknown, O=Unknown, L=Unknown, ST=Unknown, C=Unknown
  Signature Algorithm: SHA256withRSA, OID = 1.2.840.113549.1.1.11
 
  Key:  Sun RSA public key, 2048 bits
  modulus: 
  public exponent: 65537
  Validity: [From: Thu Oct 06 21:13:02 UTC 2016,
               To: Wed Jan 04 21:13:02 UTC 2017]
  Issuer: CN=fecru.internal.jeffjeff.local, OU=Unknown, O=Unknown, L=Unknown, ST=Unknown, C=Unknown
  SerialNumber: [    4b0913a4]{code}

h3.Workaround

* Set {{clientAuth="false"}} in Crowd
* Set up an additional connector in Crowd which does not have {{clientAuth}} enabled
fields.summary: Crowd HTTP client ignores SSL system properties

fields.description:
The Crowd LDAP directory connector allowed an attacker to gain remote code execution in Crowd by injecting malicious attributes in LDAP entries. To exploit this issue, attackers need to modify an entry in your LDAP directory or successfully execute a Man-in-The-Middle attack between an LDAP server and Crowd. Crowd installations configured to communicate with an LDAP server using the *LDAPS* protocol with the *Secure SSL* option enabled are immune to this attack vector only (unless an attacker is able to obtain the private key of the SSL/TLS certificate used to secure the communication).

*Affected versions:*
 * All versions of Crowd from *1.4.1* before *2.8.8* (the fixed version for 2.8.x) and from *2.9.0* before *2.9.5* (the fixed version for 2.9.x) are affected by this vulnerability.

*Fix:*
 * *Crowd* 2.10.1 is available for download from [https://www.atlassian.com/software/crowd/download].
 * *Crowd* 2.9.5 is available for download from [https://www.atlassian.com/software/crowd/download-archive].
 * *Crowd* 2.8.8 is available for download from [https://www.atlassian.com/software/crowd/download-archive].

*Risk Mitigation:*
 * The issue can be mitigated by restricting modifications of LDAP entries by LDAP users and configuring SSL/TLS connection between an LDAP Server and Crowd. See [Configuring Crowd to Work with SSL|https://confluence.atlassian.com/crowd/configuring-crowd-to-work-with-ssl-151520306.html] for information on setting up secure transport.

\\
*Acknowledgements:*
We would like to credit Alvaro Munoz and Alexander Mirosh of HPE Security Fortify for reporting this issue to us.

\\
For additional details see the [full advisory|https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/wykQMw].
fields.summary: CVE-2016-6496: LDAP Java Object Injection in Crowd

fields.description:
When there is a local proxy in front of any Atlassian application using Crowd, the reported client IP can be 127.0.0.1. Usually clients configure the public IPs in Crowd trusted proxies and then 127.0.0.1 will be reported as the client IP. 
If all application are behind such proxy this goes unnoticed and is some kind of security issue. If only some application are behind such proxy the token validation fails when validating the remote address. Could we add by default 127.0.0.1 to the list of trusted proxies by default?
fields.summary: Adding 127.0.0.1 by default to the list of Crowd trusted proxies?

fields.description:
{panel:title=Atlassian Update - 8 June 2020|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#3c78b5|titleBGColor=#3c78b5|bgColor=#e7f4fa}
Hello everyone,

We have recently reviewed this issue and the overall interest in the problem. As the issue hasn't collect votes, watchers, comments, or support cases from many customers during its lifetime, it's very low on our priority list, and will not be fixed in the foreseeable future. That's why we've decided to resolve it as *Timed Out*.

Although we're aware the issue is still important to those of you who were involved in the conversations around it, we want to be clear in managing your expectations. The Crowd team is focusing on issues that have broad impact and high value, reflected by the number of comments, votes, support cases, and customers interested. Please consult the [Atlassian Bugfix Policy|https://confluence.atlassian.com/support/atlassian-server-bug-fix-policy-201294573.html] for more details.

We understand how disappointing this decision may be, but we hope you'll appreciate our transparent approach and communication.

Atlassian will continue to watch this issue for further updates, so please feel free to share your thoughts in the comments.

Thank you,

Crowd Team
{panel}
h3.  
h3. Summary

It was observed that a user is removed from an Atlassian application using Embedded Crowd (e.g. Bitbucket Server) if Bitbucket Server uses JIRA for user authentication and the user is renamed in JIRA, and then JIRA is connected to an external user directory (e.g. Crowd) which contains a user with the same username before the renamed user is synced into Bitbucket Server. The new username will show up in Bitbucket Server, but it will actually be a new user.

I've classified this as Critical as this impacts all the permissions of the renamed users, and the only workaround is to manually set all the permissions again.
h3. Environment

This have been tested with the following versions:
 * Crowd 2.8.3 / 2.9.1
 * JIRA Software 7.2.1
 * Bitbucket Server 4.8.3 / Confluence 5.10.5

h3. Steps to Reproduce

Before initiating the steps, configure Crowd as follows:
 # Create a directory dedicated to JIRA (e.g. *JIRA*).
 # Create a group under the *JIRA* directory (e.g. *jira-software-users*).
 # Create a user under the *JIRA* directory named *refoscog*, and make this user part of the *jira-software-users* group.
 # Create an application for JIRA to connect to it (e.g. *jira*), allowing the directory *JIRA* and the group *jira-software-users* to authenticate gainst it.

Assume clean instances to reproduce the steps below, still not connected among each other:
 # In JIRA, create a user called *grefosco*.
 # In JIRA, add a JIRA User Server to allow Bitbucket Server to connect to it.
 # In Bitbucket Server, create a user directory to connect to JIRA and synchronize it. The user *grefosco* will be pulled from JIRA.
 # In Bitbucket Server, give *grefosco* a Global Permission of *Bitbucket User*.
 # In Bitbucket Server, go to a project settings (e.g. a project called *PROJ*) and give *grefosco* any permission on this project.
 # In JIRA, rename the user *grefosco* to *refoscog*.
 # In JIRA, add a user directory connecting it to the application *jira* in Crowd, then synchronize this directory.
 # In JIRA, move the Crowd directory to the top of the list.
 # In Bitbucket Server, re-sync the JIRA directory.

h3. Expected Results
 * The user *grefosco* in Bitbucket Server is renamed to *refoscog*, and all references to it are properly updated.

h3. Actual Results
 * The user *grefosco* is removed from Bitbucket Server and a new user *refoscog* is created.
 * Checking project permissions will show the user *grefosco* struck through.

h3. Notes

This behavior happens because:
 # The user is renamed in JIRA.
 # Before re-syncing the change into Bitbucket Server, JIRA is connected with Crowd, and the Crowd directory is moved to the top of the list, so the current *refoscog* user in JIRA's user list is the one coming from Crowd, not the one that was renamed in JIRA.
 # When Bitbucket syncs with JIRA, it searches for users whose external ID correspond to its already added *grefosco*'s external ID. Since it can't find this user anymore, instead of renaming it, the user is renamed from Bitbucket's {{cwd_user}} table.

h3. Workaround
h4. Workaround 1: Revert the changes and repeat the process in a different order

If no new information has been created in JIRA or Bitbucket Server, you may restore both applications from the latest backup available, and start the process all over again, this time following the order below:
 # Rename the user in JIRA to reflect the username in Crowd.
 # Re-sync the JIRA directory in Bitbucket Server, so the rename is applied.
 # Add the Crowd directory to JIRA, sync it and move the Crowd directory to the top of the list.
 # Run the sync in Bitbucket Server again.

It's still possible to revert only Bitbucket Server, following some additional steps though:
 # In JIRA, move the JIRA internal directory to the top of the directories list.
 # In JIRA, rename the users back to their old username, matching the ones you have in Bitbucket Server.
 # Restore Bitbucket Server.
 # Follow the 4 steps listed above, under *Workaround 1*.

h4. Workaround 2: Set your permissions again
 # If it's not possible to revert, you'll need to set all the permissions again for the renamed users.
fields.summary: User is removed when renaming the corresponding user on the external directory (e.g. JIRA) and connecting the external directory to an external source (e.g. Crowd) containing the same username, prior to sync the user renamed into the application

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

If the Crowd directory is configured to disallow repeated/old passwords on password change,  the reset attempt will be rejected if the user attempts to input a repeated/old password. 

The problem is that after the user attempts to key in a new password afterward the rejected attempt, it will display an error message saying that the password token is now invalid and the user will be required to request for a new token.

h3. Suggested Solution

Either one of the following:
# After the initial password reset attempt is rejected, the user should be notified that the password reset token is now invalid and be prompted to create a new one instead immediately.
# Allow the user to continue with the password reset attempt and reset their password to an accepted one.
fields.summary: Users should be alerted that the password reset token is invalid after a failed password reset attempt.

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

Using Crowd as Single Sign-on you can sign in to Chrome in order to store browser specific settings to your corporate/personal account.
 If you change the password of this account, Chrome requests you to login again. When this happens, Crowd opens multiple tabs all containing the login screen and even if you login from those tabs, the login does not work.

You are successfully logged in and you are redirected to the home page (following a successful login) but Chrome is still not authenticated.
 Different people experience different set of symptoms.
 - 5 tabs open at the same time
 - Wait time up to 4 minutes before getting any response from the server
 - User had to delete the existing account and create a new one in order to sync properly

h3. Suggested Solution

Make this process easier and more user friendly.
fields.summary: Crowd takes long time to sign in with Chrome after password change

fields.description:
As of now, Crowd is not able to detect changes in LDAP groups and its causing other Atlassian application that uses Embedded Crowd not to be able to keep track of individual application's permission as what a group rename is perceived now is by removing the old group name and adding the new group name. This causes tracking problems to individual permission types (whether its Global Permission, Permission Scheme and etc) for each application as they do not 'update' those permissions with the new group name. 

h5. Steps to reproduce:
# Connect Bitbucket Server/JIRA/Confluence/FishEye/Crucible to and LDAP user directory
# Create a group, {{groupA}} on LDAP and sync it over
# Grant the group a Global permission
# Rename the group in LDAP.
# Re-synchronize the LDAP directory.
# Verify that the name of the group the users belong to was updated
# Check Global Permission and see the original group name is still listed, and the new group name is not listed.

h5. Workaround:
Manually add the new group name into Global Permission. However this is a problem when the number of group gets larger by time.
fields.summary: Inability for Crowd to detect renamed LDAP groups as Crowd does not track using its LDAP IDs yet

fields.description:
Consider the following scenario:

Tom Fubar has two accounts on different Active Directories. *tom.fubar@DOM1* and *tom.fubar@DOM2*

An internal application using Crowd for its authentication is set to use these directories, with DOM1 above DOM2 in the priority list.

If Tom's account is disabled on DOM1, but not DOM2, and Tom tries to log in to the application with his DOM2 credentials, Crowd will record an authentication failure against DOM1 and immediately fail the attempt, not even trying DOM2. Furthermore, the disabled user state is not checked before trying to validate the password, causing the BadPasswordCount to be incremented.

*Ideally, Crowd could be configured to see that the account is disabled, not bother trying to auth against it, and try the next directory in the list.*

A workaround for this is to configure the Crowd user filter for DOM1 to hide accounts that are disabled; this can be accomplished by including:

 {{(!(userAccountControl:1.2.840.113556.1.4.803:=2)) }}

..somewhere in the user filter in Crowd, but this may not be appropriate for all use cases.
fields.summary: Crowd should check user enabled status before trying to authenticate against an external directory, and optionally authenticate against lower priority directories

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

When a user has an application set which includes one in which a user is not allowed access, any attempt to access this application causes the session to be end, and subsequently the user is logged out of all other applications.

For example: 

* User has access to JIRA1
* User has access to Confluence 
* User does not have access to JIRA2

# User attempts to access JIRA1 - success
# User is logged into Confluence - success
# User attempts to login to JIRA2 - fails
# User is logged out of all applications

h3. Suggested Solution
 
Do not end session for applications with successful authentication when user does not pass authentication checks for one application.

h3. Workaround

There is no workaround known.
fields.summary: Crowd SSO - Prevent session end for all other applications when a user is not successfully authenticated to one of them
Add ability to restrict token IP validation only to 'x-forwarded-for'

fields.description:
h3. Summary

Crowd SSO does not update last login date for Users from Confluence DataCenter because of Cookie Set


h3. Environment
Crowd 2.9.1
Confluence 5.9.9 Datacenter 


h3. Steps to Reproduce

# Configure Crowd and Confluence DataCenter with SSO.
# Have UserA login to Confluence. UserA automatically gets a "Remember Me" cookie. 
# Check the Crowd database for the last login time of UserA and it shows the login from step2. 
# Quit the browser from Step2. 
# Open a new browser, go to the Confluence login and UserA is still logged in because DataCenter automatically had the "Remember Me" option enabled.
# Check the Crowd database for the last login time of UserA and it still shows the login time from Step 2 and did not update with the login time from step 5. In the Confluence admin section UserA's login time shows from step5.

h3. Expected Results

Crowd should update the database with the last login time since the Confluence datavase is updating the last login time even though the "Remember me" cookie is set.

h3. Actual Results

Crowd does not sync with Confluence for the last login time when the "Remember me" cookie is set. Confluence Datacenter automatically enables the cookie and there is not an option to disable the cookie.

h3. Notes
This issue was reported by a Premiere customer in PS-5882. The customer is using the last login time in Crowd to disable users that are not active for X amount of days so they do not have to query each individual Atlassian application and can just query Crowd. This is related to [CWD-4749| https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CWD-4749].


h3.Workaround

No workaround
fields.summary: Last Login Date is Not Updated from Confluence Datacenter

fields.description:
h4. Problem: 

Crowd doesn't remove the "Remember me" cookies: {{seraph.confluence}}, 
{{seraph.rememberme.cookie}} and {{_atl_bitbucket_remember_me}} when you logout from applications that are connected to it and using SSO. Given that, if you close the browser and open it again, you are already logged in.

For JIRA Data Center and Bitbucket Data Center, you have the option to check the "Remember me" option as outlined in the following screenshots:

 !bb_remember_me.png|thumbnail! 
 !jira_remember_me.png|thumbnail! 

So this problem only happens when the Rememer me option is *checked*. 

However, for Confluence *Data Center* , the "Remember me" option is hidden:
 !confluence_no_remember_me.png|thumbnail! 

When that option is hidden, the "Remember me" token  {{seraph.rememberme.cookie}} is set by default (value="true"):
{code}
                        #if ($action.shouldRememberMeCheckboxBeOmitted())
                            <input type="hidden" name="os_cookie" value="true"/>
                        #else
                            #bodytag( "Component" "label='remember.accesskey'" "name='os_cookie'" "value='false'" "theme='aui'" "template='onofflist.vm'") #end
                        #end
{code}

This is designed this way because data center relies on that cookie {{seraph.confluence}} to distribute the load between the nodes. 

(i) One thing to note is that {{seraph.confluence}} cookie is *only generated* if when you open the browser and login through Confluence. If you login through any other application, that cookie *is not generated*.

h4.How to test this:

Test One:

* Open Chrome and go to {{Settings > show advanced settings > clear browsing data}} and clear everything from the beginning of times
* Now, open Confluence and login
* Check your browser's cookies ((Settings > show advanced settings > content settings > All cookies and site data)). The {{seraph.confluence}} cookie is set for your domain (localhost, on my tests)
* Now, login to JIRA 
* Logout from JIRA and close the browser
* Open the browser again and check your cookies again. The {{seraph.confluence}} is still there
* Open Confluence. Since the {{seraph.confluence}} cookie still exists, you are not asked to login to Confluence (not the expected behavior)

Test Two:

* Close all tabs and clear your browser's cache: {{Settings > show advanced settings > clear browsing data}} and clear everything from the begging of times
* Login to JIRA
* Open a new tab and open Confluence, you should be automatically logged in.
* Check your browser's cookies ((Settings > show advanced settings > content settings > All cookies and site data)). The {{seraph.confluence}} cookie is not there
* Logout from JIRA
* Close the browser
* Open the browser again and try to login to Confluence. Since the {{seraph.confluence}} cookie doesn't exist, you will be asked *as expected* to login to Confluence


h4.Proposed Fix: 

When logging out of applications that are using SSO, all cookies (including the "Remember Me") ones should be cleared as well.
fields.summary: Inconsistent SSO behavior when using Data Center

fields.description:
h3. Summary
This was reported on a Stash/Bitbucket Server instance with embedded Crowd. Using LDAP with local groups, having a local group named "foo", and then adding the group 'foo' in the LDAP directory will cause it to not synchronise, but the user is unable to delete the local group either. Stash/Bitbucket Server Logs report:
{noformat}
2016-03-10 18:32:25,522 DEBUG [clusterScheduler_Worker-7]  c.a.c.d.DbCachingRemoteChangeOperations group [ foo ] in directory [ 917505 ] matches local group of same name, skipping
{noformat}
h3. Environment
* Stash 3.11.2
* LDAP has been configured with "Read Only, with Local Groups" in Stash/Bitbucket Server.
* Membership Aggregation enabled in Stash/Bitbucket Server
* Nested Groups enabled
* LDAP user directory is set at the highest priority (first user directory)

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Configure Stash/Bitbucket Server with LDAP with local groups
# Create a local group name "foo" to match an extsing LDAP group "foo"
# Trigger a sync with LDAP

h3. Expected Results
Group Memberships are synced for users correctly that belong to the "foo" group.

h3. Actual Results
Group Memberships are empty or not synced correctly for users belonging to group "foo" and following message is reported in Stash/Bitbucket Server logs:
{noformat}
2016-03-10 18:32:25,522 DEBUG [clusterScheduler_Worker-7]  c.a.c.d.DbCachingRemoteChangeOperations group [ foo ] in directory [ 917505 ] matches local group of same name, skipping
{noformat} 
Additionally, the local group can't be removed via the UI.
h3. Notes
Querying the Stash/Bitbucket Server database on the "cwd_group" table shows that there are two groups by the name of "foo" - one local and one LDAP but both are enabled:
{noformat}
| 4128772 | foo                                          | foo                                          | 2014-10-29 07:29:20 | 2014-10-29 07:29:20 | NULL                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 | GROUP      |       917505 | T         | T        |
{noformat}
{noformat}
| 6783242 | foo                                          | foo                                          | 2016-02-18 17:21:29 | 2016-02-18 17:21:29 | NULL                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 | GROUP      |      1802241 | T         | F        |
{noformat}
Note that the Directory id '917505' corresponds to the local user directory and has the "is_local" field set to 'T'.

h3.Workaround
# Ensure you have a complete backup of your Stash/Bitbucket Server instance.
# Stop the application
# Update the above record in your database for local user directory '917505' and set the 'is_local' flag to 'F'.
# Restart the application.
# Note that if the group has any local memberships (that are not on the remote LDAP server), these would be lost after the change. The following might be reported in Stash/Bitbucket Server logs on subsequent synchronization with the LDAP server:
{noformat}
2016-05-19 07:49:00,567 DEBUG [clusterScheduler_Worker-4]  c.a.s.i.crowd.HibernateMembershipDao Deleting object: com.atlassian.crowd.model.membership.InternalMembership@5f84bbfd[parentId=4128772,childId=983314,membershipType=GROUP_USER,groupType=GROUP,parentName=foo,lowerParentName=foo,childName=foochild,lowerChildName=foochild,directoryId=917505]
2016-05-19 07:49:00,567 DEBUG [clusterScheduler_Worker-4]  c.a.s.i.e.TransactionAwareEventPublisher Deferring publishing for GroupMembershipDeletedEvent until AFTER_COMMIT

2016-05-19 07:49:00,573 INFO  [clusterScheduler_Worker-4]  c.a.c.d.DbCachingRemoteChangeOperations removed [ 1 ] user members from [ foo ] in [ 14ms ]
2016-05-19 07:49:00,577 DEBUG [clusterScheduler_Worker-4]  c.a.s.i.e.TransactionAwareEventPublisher Publishing GroupMembershipDeletedEvent after commit
{noformat}
fields.summary: Synchronisation with a LDAP group fails if there also exists a duplicate local group

fields.description:
h2. Problem summary
Currently a user directory can only be configured to accept one base DN for users, and one base DN for users. If users or groups (that are relevant to Crowd) exist in multiple containers/OUs of the LDAP structure, then the base DN has to be set wide enough so that both OUs are in scope of the search. This can cause too many irrelevant groups to be pulled into Crowd, which in turn leads to performance issues or complexity in maintaining user management.

h2. Example
For example: consider the case where we have the following LDAP structure, for simplicity's sake we're only looking for groups right now and not users:
{code}
DC=company,DC=com
  +--- OU=all_groups
         +--- OU=amer_groups
         +--- OU=apac_groups
         +--- OU=50k_other_irrelevant_groups
{code}

If we want to pull in the groups under {{amer_groups}} and {{apac_groups}}, then the group base DN must be set to {{"OU=all_groups,DC=company,DC=com}}" since both of of them are under that common OU.

The problem is, doing so will also pull the other 50k groups we don't care about into Crowd, because that's also within the search scope. For some LDAP implementations, this is not a problem because you can exclude those irrelevant groups by using [Extensible Matching|https://ldapwiki.willeke.com/wiki/ExtensibleMatch] in a search filter to target groups that are within specific OUs. However some LDAP implementations, most notably Microsoft Active Directory, do [not support this type of filtering|https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/cc223241.aspx], and therefore Crowd will have no choice but to pull in all of the groups.

h2. Workarounds and limitations
In current versions of Crowd, administrators can somewhat work around this by using multiple user directories. For example, one directory will have the group base DN set to {{"OU=amer_groups,OU=all_groups,DC=example,DC=com"}}, and another set to {{"OU=apac_groups,OU=all_groups,DC=example,DC=com"}}. However, this is not ideal, as both of these directories will still need to pull in _all_ users so that their group memberships can be aggregated across user directories. The work to pull in users is duplicated.

h2. Proposed solution
It would be ideal if Crowd itself can allow a single directory to search for users/groups from multiple DNs, regardless of the AD/LDAP implementation.
fields.summary: Support for multiple base DNs for users/groups in a single user directory

fields.description:

fields.description:
In the Further Information section of the support documentation page at https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWD/Recovering+your+Console+application+password, we claim that the password is "encrypted" using SHA1. This is technically incorrect and has been pointed out by an external user. SHA1 is a hashing algorithm and is technically different from encryption/decryption. The security team recommends updating the documentation to make this clear, changing the bullet to indicate that the password is "persisted as a SHA1 hash", if this is still the case.

References
http://twitter.com/bloudraak/status/737554107683082240
fields.summary: Technically Incorrect Terminology in Support Documentation

fields.description:
We currently recommend customers set a specific password in our support documentation for Crowd when they encounter an issue linked to an authentication-related exception. The information can be found at the following link: https://confluence.atlassian.com/crowdkb/getting-invalidauthenticationexception-in-the-log-file-when-logging-into-crowd-234653175.html. This is bad security practice.

The security team strongly recommends updating the support documentation to describe how to set a password chosen by the customer, not a static default. We should also recommend setting a sufficiently complex password and describe how the password hash is derived to better enable control by administrators.

References:
http://twitter.com/bloudraak/status/737511014594269184
fields.summary: Default Password "Resolution" in Crowd Support Documentation

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
Currently, Crowd does not have a script to uninstall the application. We also do not have any documentation on how to do this.

h3. Suggested Solution
It would be great if  we could provide a default uninstall script such as the one outlined in the following page for Confluence: [Uninstalling Confluence from Linux|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/DOC/Uninstalling+Confluence+from+Linux]

h3. Workaround 
Remove the following from your instance:
* Crowd home directory
* Crowd install directory
* Crowd database
* If Crowd was configured as a service - uninstall the service as well
fields.summary: Provide uninstall script for Crowd

fields.summary: Api changes in 2.9.1

fields.description:
Currently we allow modifying whether a connector directory is cached or not at any time. This is done on the details screen using the 'Cache enabled' checkbox. Checking this impacts the behaviour (for example when switching from cached to non-cached the cached data in the db is no longer used, but is left behind in the db), and affects some related settings (things like synchronisation interval, incremental sync, authentication behaviour settings from CWD-4197), but it's not very clear which settings are related to synchronisation.

Some things to consider:
* disallow changing the cached/noncached configuration after directory creation
* present the cached setting on the same screen as the rest of the directory config settings (the 'Connector' tab), and make it show or hide the related section
* other?
fields.summary: Rethink/rework UI around directory configuration

fields.description: Consider situation where we change password for LDAP directory. After that pooled connections are not being reset, which leads to situation where Crowd cannot contact remote LDAP directory
fields.summary: Crowd should refresh pooled LDAP connections after configuration changed

fields.description:
When synchronisation removes a large number of users (because of config changes usually, easy to replicate by changing the 'User name attribute' after an initial sync), these are intended to be batched for fast removal. 

Unfortunately after the removal we publish UserDeletedEvents one-by-one, and the listeners (notably UserDirectoryTokenRemovalListener, potentially others) do one-by-one processing in the same Hibernate session, causing very slow operation.

Observed effect is seeing "Removing X users from the cache" for a very long time during synchronisation. Tested for 10000 users, where adding them took seconds, removal took over ten minutes.

Example stacktrace is:
{code}
        at org.hibernate.internal.SessionImpl.flush(SessionImpl.java:1159)

        at org.springframework.transaction.interceptor.TransactionInterceptor.invoke(TransactionInterceptor.java:94)

        at org.springframework.aop.framework.JdkDynamicAopProxy.invoke(JdkDynamicAopProxy.java:204)
        at com.sun.proxy.$Proxy26.remove(Unknown Source)
        at sun.reflect.GeneratedMethodAccessor524.invoke(Unknown Source)
        at sun.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.java:43)
        at java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Method.java:497)
        at org.springframework.aop.support.AopUtils.invokeJoinpointUsingReflection(AopUtils.java:317)
        at org.springframework.aop.framework.ReflectiveMethodInvocation.invokeJoinpoint(ReflectiveMethodInvocation.java:183)
        at org.springframework.aop.framework.ReflectiveMethodInvocation.proceed(ReflectiveMethodInvocation.java:150)
        at com.atlassian.spring.interceptors.SpringProfilingInterceptor.invoke(SpringProfilingInterceptor.java:16)
        at org.springframework.aop.framework.ReflectiveMethodInvocation.proceed(ReflectiveMethodInvocation.java:172)
        at org.springframework.aop.framework.JdkDynamicAopProxy.invoke(JdkDynamicAopProxy.java:204)

        at com.google.common.util.concurrent.MoreExecutors$DirectExecutorService.execute(MoreExecutors.java:299)
        at com.atlassian.event.internal.AsynchronousAbleEventDispatcher.dispatch(AsynchronousAbleEventDispatcher.java:107)
        at com.atlassian.event.internal.EventPublisherImpl.invokeListeners(EventPublisherImpl.java:160)
        at com.atlassian.event.internal.EventPublisherImpl.publish(EventPublisherImpl.java:79)
        at com.atlassian.crowd.util.TransactionalEventPublisher.publish(TransactionalEventPublisher.java:25)

        at java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Method.java:497)
        at org.springframework.aop.support.AopUtils.invokeJoinpointUsingReflection(AopUtils.java:317)
        at org.springframework.aop.framework.ReflectiveMethodInvocation.invokeJoinpoint(ReflectiveMethodInvocation.java:183)

        at org.springframework.transaction.interceptor.TransactionAspectSupport.invokeWithinTransaction(TransactionAspectSupport.java:260)
        at org.springframework.transaction.interceptor.TransactionInterceptor.invoke(TransactionInterceptor.java:94)
        at org.springframework.aop.framework.ReflectiveMethodInvocation.proceed(ReflectiveMethodInvocation.java:172)
        at org.springframework.aop.framework.JdkDynamicAopProxy.invoke(JdkDynamicAopProxy.java:204)
        at com.sun.proxy.$Proxy20.publish(Unknown Source)
        at com.atlassian.crowd.directory.DbCachingRemoteChangeOperations.publishEvent(DbCachingRemoteChangeOperations.java:1065)

{code}

Solutions to consider:
* replacing event handlers with batched removals
* replace with async events
* replace with multi-user event
* manage the Hibernate session better, preventing it from growing - the main cost seems to be dirty checking which is something we've seen before for large sessions

This probably affects directory management in products as well, consider that when determining a solution.

fields.description:
Is there a way to manually change the Password Expiry parameter in Crowd? 

We have attempted to implement a solution stated in the a attached link with no success. In the following file we added the following lines:

/opt/atlassian/atlassian-crowd-2.8.4/crowd-webapp/WEB-INF/classes/crowd-ehcache.xml

<cache name="com.atlassian.crowd.model.token.ResetPasswordToken"
           maxElementsInMemory="1024"
           overflowToDisk="true"
           diskPersistent="true"
           timeToIdleSeconds="300"
           timeToLiveSeconds="300"
           />

After applying the change we restarted Crowd, generated a reset Link for a user, and found that the link was still valid after 5 minutes.

https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/149767/change-crowd-password-reset-token-expiry-period-from-24-hours
fields.summary: Please add a method for changing the Password Expiry Threshold from the default 24 Hours

fields.description:
The current documentation to [Configure Crowd to start automatically on Linux|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWD/Setting+Crowd+to+Run+Automatically+and+Use+an+Unprivileged+System+User+on+UNIX] is outdated and needs improvement to match [Confluence|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/DOC/Start+Confluence+Automatically+on+Linux] and [Jira|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA064/Starting+JIRA+Automatically+on+Linux] configuration.

We've had some customers complain about a bug where the stop command {{service crowd stop}} does not kill the actual process. 
On the contrary, when using {{stop-crowd.sh}} this problem does not occur.

A fix was shipped with Crowd 2.8.4 (bug reference: [CWD-4423|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CWD-4423]), however the script in the documentation still lacks a fix. Here's the bug for it [CWD-2070|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CWD-2070]
fields.summary: Improve Setting Crowd to Run Automatically Documentation

fields.description: Potentially it would be good to verify other settings like charset, storage engine etc.
fields.summary: Provide a setup check for MySQL database in order to verify if read committed isolation level is set

fields.description:
h4. Steps to Reproduce:

# Add a directory in Crowd _(e.g. {{testDirectory}})_.
# Add a group in Crowd for {{testDirectory}} _(e.g. {{testGroup}})_.
# Add {{testGroup}} to {{testDirectory}}.
# Navigate to Application and choose *crowd* _(Crowd console)_.
# In Directories tab add {{testDirectory}}.
# Navigate to Groups tab and add {{testGroup}} to the crowd application.
# Assign *System Administrator* permission.
# Open Directory and try to remove {{testDirectory}}.

h4. Actual Behaviour:

h4. Expected Behaviour:

Crowd should remove the directory.

The ability to change the timer through the UI or local file.

fields.description:
Note: I tested in Crowd 2.9.1 not 2.9. 
2.9.1 was not on the pulldown.
h3. Summary
Users in a delegated LDAP directory cannot log into HipChat unless their user account has already been created by logging into another application connected to Crowd. 

h3. Environment
* HipChat Server 1.3.7
* Crowd 2.9.1

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Set up a delegated LDAP directory in Crowd 2.9.1
# Set up HipChat application in Crowd
# Map a group from LDAP to the HipChat application
# Set up the Crowd User Directory in HipChat
# Log into HipChat as a user in the mapped group

h3. Expected Results
The user logs into HipChat, authenticating against the LDAP directory

h3. Actual Results
The user cannot log in, bad username/password message

h3. Notes
* The issue is unlike https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONF-22105 because the failed attempt to log into HipChat does not create the user in Crowd.
* One theory is that Crowd searches the LDAP directory based on username, whereas the email field is used by HipChat.

h3.Workaround 1
# Map the delegated directory to the Crowd application so users can log into Crowd
# Log the user into Crowd using the LDAP username (not the email address) 
# Sync the Crowd directory in HipChat
# Log into HipChat with the email address

h3. Workaround 2
Use a Connector in Crowd rather than a delegating directory.

h3. Workaround 3 
Change the User name attribute in the Crowd Delegated directory to "email" (for AD)
fields.summary: Delegated LDAP users cannot log into HipChat unless created in Crowd first

fields.description: When Tomcat was upgraded (CWD-4626), the default behaviour to use relative URLs in redirections was overridden. Revert to this behaviour, for slightly smaller headers and for consistency with Tomcat defaults.
fields.summary: Configure Tomcat to use relative URLs in redirections

fields.description:
Currently it is possible to automatically add a user into a group when the user first authenticate. This have to be done in the directory configuration itself. 

However, it is much convenient if we could add the similar functionality in the Application configuration so that we could add user into a group based on which application the user belongs to.
fields.summary: Allow Crowd to add user into a group automatically based on Application when user first authenticate

fields.description:
When clicking the 'Revert to defaults' on the 'Logging & profiling' screen the logging system is not reconfigured properly, and all logging to the default logfile stops.

We need to:
* make sure {{com.atlassian.crowd.console.logging.CrowdHomeLogAppender#switchAppender}} is called when doing com.atlassian.crowd.console.action.options.UpdateLoggingProfiling#updateLogging
* make sure to close the inputstream in com.atlassian.crowd.console.action.options.UpdateLoggingProfiling#updateLogging
fields.summary: Clicking 'Revert to defaults' on the 'Logging & profiling' screen stops logging to logfile

fields.description:
Searching users by their attribute values in an Internal/Cached directory performs badly because the index on attribute values is not being used by Postgres.

This is the query executed by Crowd:

{noformat}
select distinct internalus0_.id as id1_17_, internalus0_.user_name as user_nam2_17_, internalus0_.lower_user_name as lower_us3_17_, internalus0_.active as active4_17_, internalus0_.created_date as created_5_17_, internalus0_.updated_date as updated_6_17_, internalus0_.first_name as first_na7_17_, internalus0_.lower_first_name as lower_fi8_17_, internalus0_.last_name as last_nam9_17_, internalus0_.lower_last_name as lower_l10_17_, internalus0_.display_name as display11_17_, internalus0_.lower_display_name as lower_d12_17_, internalus0_.email_address as email_a13_17_, internalus0_.lower_email_address as lower_e14_17_, internalus0_.external_id as externa15_17_, internalus0_.directory_id as directo16_17_, internalus0_.credential as credent17_17_
from cwd_user internalus0_
left outer join cwd_user_attribute attributes1_
  on internalus0_.id=attributes1_.user_id
where internalus0_.directory_id=$1
  and internalus0_.id=attributes1_.user_id
  and attributes1_.attribute_name=$2
  and attributes1_.attribute_lower_value=$3
order by internalus0_.lower_user_name
{noformat}

This is how Postgres EXPLAINs the execution of the query:

{noformat}
 Unique  (cost=830299.92..830300.28 rows=8 width=257)
   ->  Sort  (cost=830299.92..830299.94 rows=8 width=257)
         Sort Key: internalus0_.lower_user_name, internalus0_.id, internalus0_.user_name, internalus0_.active, internalus0_.created_date, internalus0_.updated_date, internalus0_.first_name, internalus0_.lower_first_name, internalus0_.last_name, internalus0_.lower_last_name, internalus0_.display_name, internalus0_.lower_display_name, internalus0_.email_address, internalus0_.lower_email_address, internalus0_.external_id, internalus0_.credential
         ->  Nested Loop  (cost=0.43..830299.80 rows=8 width=257)
               ->  Seq Scan on cwd_user_attribute attributes1_  (cost=0.00..830232.08 rows=8 width=8)
                     Filter: (((attribute_name)::text = '<EDITED>'::text) AND ((attribute_lower_value)::text = '<EDITED>'::text))
               ->  Index Scan using cwd_user_pkey on cwd_user internalus0_  (cost=0.43..8.46 rows=1 width=257)
                     Index Cond: (id = attributes1_.user_id)
                     Filter: (directory_id = <EDITED>)
{noformat}

Note the Seq Scan of the attributes, which is not using the existing index:

{noformat}
    "idx_user_attr_dir_name_lval" btree (directory_id, attribute_name, attribute_lower_value)
{noformat}
fields.summary: Searching users by their attributes should use existing index in attribute table

fields.description:
When search direct group relationship or search nested group relationship is performed Crowd is doing additional `is canonical` check which involves talking again to directories to get information if the user / group is defined there.

Judging from code it looks like it could be done in memory only without the need of talking to directories again.
fields.summary: Improve isCanonical check in InMemoryNonAggregatingSearchStrategy

fields.description:
h3. Summary

When viewing the groups tab of an application in Crowd . The time taken to load this tab is high when the number of groups is large eg: 5000+. This does not happen in Crowd 2.7 .

 
h3. Environment
Crowd 2.8+

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Add a crowd application
# associate a directory to this application which has 5000+ groups
# Try to access the groups tab

h3. Expected Results
The tab should load quickly

h3. Actual Results
The tab takes time to load around 30 seconds for 5000 groups , this increasing with the number for groups
fields.summary: Groups tab under applications takes time to load when number of groups is large

fields.description:
The View Directory page for our LDAP Directory shows a continuously running synchronization process.  It shows:

Current synchronisation
Started
February 6, 2016 12:21:54 AM PST
Time taken
12 weeks, 2 days, 14 hours, 32 minutes, 53 seconds 
Status
Updating 13 users in the cache
fields.summary: LDAP directory synchronization is taking 12 weeks and counting.
